author: tuyen4818
content:
Hello All,
in my lodestar client, when I do initial sync for Medalla some peers consistently return us 0 blocks for `beacon_blocks_by_range`. I'm curious if any of us have same issues?

author: ajsutton
content: hmm, the only reason you should get 0 blocks returned is if the client thought there were no blocks in the entire requested range.  Otherwise they should return at least one.  How many slots are you requesting for each request?

author: tuyen4818
content: it's 10-20 slots per request, and I only get issue with some specific peers

author: tuyen4818
content: for all other peers, it returns me correctly

author: ajsutton
content: Interesting.  There were some peers on Altona that were throttling very aggressively and only returned 1 block, but I haven't seen one return 0.  Although, Teku would wind up disconnecting them pretty quickly for not providing the blocks they claim to have.

author: tuyen4818
content: it happens frequently, if you haven't seen it then I need to look into the way we handle `beacon_blocks_by_range` response too

author: tuyen4818
tuyen4818
content: please let me know if you know where they  are from. Thanks!

author: ajsutton
content: Teku is getting blocks returned by `/ip4/145.14.158.173/tcp/9000/p2p/16Uiu2HAmLMrZ6a2JYK4ZBiJmPSMSRTfNWomBGfoXmuwnLVhLrXvf` . So it's not always returning nothing.

author: p_bitfly
content: FYI we now show the attestation effectiveness for each validator as per https://www.attestant.io/posts/defining-attestation-effectiveness see https://beaconcha.in/validator/3491 for an example, anybody knows why attestations take so long to be included in blocks?

author: nishant0
content: Those seem very low

author: nishant0
content: for everyone

author: nishant0
content:
very cool, I just saw there is an inclusion distance field, on individual validators
https://beaconcha.in/validator/20906#attestations

author: p_bitfly
content: yeah, the network average is somewhere around 16 slots distance

author: nishant0
content: not a good number ðŸ˜¬ , I was assuming it would be much smaller

author: nishant0
content: it signifies issues with attestation aggregation across the network

author: p_bitfly
content: note that our implementation right now is not 100% correct as it does not take into account skipped slots

author: jgm
content:
<@!97774605351010304> I think you may be calculating it incorrectly.

You should only calculate this for the *first* time you see the attestation.  I suspect you're overwriting the value each time you see it.

author: p_bitfly
content: as per <@!144468805697929216> s definition of the attestation effectiveness

author: p_bitfly
content: <@144468805697929216> you mean if an attestation is included multiple times?

author: p_bitfly
content: that could be the case yes

author: jgm
content: Yes

author: p_bitfly
content: let me check that

author: jgm
content: For example, validator 20906 attested for slot 13258 and it was included in slot 13259, but you show an inclusion distance of 18.

author: p_bitfly
content: good catch

author: p_bitfly
content: fixed now

author: p_bitfly
content: looking much better now

author: nishant0
content: on an initial look numbers look a lot better now

author: p_bitfly
content: hm isn't it somehow wastefull to include the attestations over and over again or is this mitigated by the aggregation feature?

author: ajsutton
content: Most likely itâ€™s not just included repeatedly but different aggregates that include partially overlapping validators. Some of the validators are duplicate but itâ€™s still worth including because others are new.

author: butta
content:
<@!144468805697929216>  a bad attestation effectives also implies higher odds of missing a block proposal, right? or at least the inclusion delay in general? 
is there a specific threshold at which it might get concerning for the user?

author: p_bitfly
content: ok, now things are looking much better https://beaconcha.in/validator/11533#overview

author: nishant0
content: <@!471975503859810316> An block proposer will have a lot of overlapping attestations to choose from , so it is expected to include already included attestations

author: p_bitfly
content: ah okay, I gues that is beacuse the aggregation is incremental

author: p_bitfly
content: my was under the impression only the block producers are aggregating the attestations

author: nishant0
content: yeap pretty much, ultimately the proposer will include the aggregates that are the most profitable to it

author: p_bitfly
content: ok, so it is not the case that the block producers have access to all individual atts and choose from them

author: p_bitfly
content: they only have access to aggregated ones

author: nishant0
content: Not just the block producer, also the aggregator. The aggregator primarily aggregates all the individual attestations

author: nishant0
content: block producers usually do not have access to individual attestations, those mostly fall to the aggregator

author: nishant0
content: the aggregator will the broadcast their aggrgegates throughout the network, and block proposers will package those aggregates into blocks

author: p_bitfly
content: kk understood
